Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Talking About Leaving Revisited: Exploring the Contribution of Teaching in Undergraduate Persistence in the Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a mixed-methods research project to explore what has and has not changed in the learning experiences of undergraduates in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors since the original study by Elaine Seymour and Nancy Hewitt, "Talking about Leaving: Why Undergraduates Leave the Sciences (TAL-1)," published in 1997. The study is focusing on the impact on student persistence of a variety of factors. This is also the first large scale investigation of STEM field-switching since TAL-1 across multiple institutions that are changing teaching practices and forms of student support in foundational STEM courses. This study is exploring whether and how problems with the learning experience found to be major contributors to switching decisions have been addressed at the original sample of seven institutions, and whether such changes enable more students to graduate in these disciplines. The seven institutions provide a useful baseline to gauge the extent of changes in the teaching and learning environment. These seven also represent the full range of types of higher education institutions providing most STEM undergraduate education (except for community colleges). Many factors affecting student decisions are being examined and independent measures of faculty teaching practices are being made using classroom visits.

The project has three inter-related component studies: (1) a study of STEM fields-switching patterns based on national and institutional data, (2) a switcher and non-switcher interview study that replicates and extends the original research, and (3) a three-part study of instructors teaching foundational STEM courses using course observation, instructor interviews, and online surveys of all students in those courses. Ethnographic data will be gathered from three sources: student interviews, instructor interviews, and students' write-in responses to the online survey. Instructor interviews will explore the processes that both enable and constrain uptake of available evidence-based teaching methods and materials. Structured classroom observation and recording will be undertaken using the Teaching Dimensions Observational Protocol (TDOP), and a custom version of the Student Assessment of their Learning Gains (SALG) online instrument will be administered to all students in the foundational courses.

Intellectual Merit: Among a number of analytical focal points, the study will produce multi-level regression analyses to assess how student demographic and academic characteristics, SALG responses, and course characteristics such as instructional methods predict the probability of students switching from their major later in the study. It will identify variables that predict switching, and the relative weight of individual predictors. These analyses will shed light on links between particular teaching methods used in foundational STEM courses and their persistence outcomes in students.

Broader Impacts: The dissemination plan for the last year of the project includes preparation of research briefs, peer-reviewed and popular articles, and a book. These will examine issues of persistence in the context of educational change. Findings will be presented at the seven research sites to audiences that include deans, directors, and chairs of STEM departments, colleges, and graduate schools; to funding agencies interested in STEM reform; to current and prospective STEM doctoral students; to faculty advisors; and to scholars of STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This five-year research study explored what has and has not changed in the learning experiences of undergraduates in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors since the original 1997 study by Seymour & Hewitt, Talking about Leaving: Why Undergraduates Leave the Sciences, and with what consequences for student persistence. We returned to six institutions participating in the original study partly because they offered a baseline, but largely because they represent the range of higher education institutions that are the normal context for most STEM undergraduate education.   

The study comprised a set of inter-related, component and collaborative studies: (1) a study of STEM field-switching patterns based on national and institutional data, (2) a switcher and non-switcher interview study that replicated and extended the original work, and (3), and online Student Assessment of their Learning Gains (SALG) survey of all students in a matched sample of 80 foundational courses across the six institutions. Select findings from two collaborating studies are referenced.     

Project findings have salience for education policy makers, the research and evaluation communities and practitioners working on STEM-education improvement. They offer an updated portrait of the extent and nature of factors shaping undergraduate persistence, including issues with relevance for particular racial and ethnic groups, and that distinguish female and male experiences of STEM education. They provide a foundation for strategies intended to improve quality, access, and persistence to graduation in STEM undergraduate education, the wider benefits of which are scientifically-capable graduates who can deploy their knowledge across a wide range of career fields in a world facing serious economic and environmental problems.   

Overview of Findings

  • Institutional study findings concur with national estimates that switching rates from STEM to non-STEM disciplines have dropped to ~28%, overall. Variations by disciplines and institutions persist (e.g., switching from biological sciences remains low; from engineering and computer science it remains high)    
  • However, the loss of STEM majors who leave college altogether (~20%) raises the STEM loss rate to ~48%—a level similar to that of 20 years ago. Who these students are and why they leave is under-studied
  • We also observe that movement (‘relocation’) from one STEM major to another has increased, as have students attempting multiple majors and minors that include a STEM major
  • Student groups who are (disproportionately) lost from STEM disciplines are still women—especially women of color—and men of color. Also lost are high-performing students—women—who are disappointed by the dull character of gateway classes and tolerate poorly low grades traditional in early STEM classes
  • Top factors affecting over 50% of switchers in our sample (N=96) show a highly interrelated mix of and intrinsic factors (loss of confidence and interest) and extrinsic factors (effects of weed-out practices in early coursework, negative STEM culture) that “push and pull” students’ decision-making process:
  1.  
    1.  
      1. Discovery of an aptitude for a non-STEM subject (76%)
      2. Loss of confidence due to low (or perceived low) grades (61%)
      3. Loss of interest in STEM: incoming interest lost (61%)
      4. Rejection of careers and associated lifestyles (58%)
      5. Shift to more appealing career option (54%)
      6. Negative effects of STEM culture: feels does not belong, problems with competitive ethos, unsupportive faculty and peers (52%)
  • Across all four years of STEM majors, we found indications of improved course design, teaching, and assessment methods, and interviewees offered clear descriptions of more and less effective teaching practices. Several forms of lecturing remain dominant in the first two years of STEM majors when loss rates are highest         
  • From institutional records and interview data, we were able to identify and define the character and consequences of classes whose teaching and assessment practices are structured to weed students out. The tacit assumption that these methods eliminate less capable, less interested or less hard-working students is unsupported by our findings. Rather, the introduction to the sciences that they offer bores and disappoints high-performing, often multi-talented majors, who have other options. It also efficiently discards many working-class students of all races and ethnicities, who, notwithstanding their high SAT and ACT scores, are less well prepared by under-resourced high schools. 

Preliminary results were presented in seven papers at the 2016 AERA Conference, at several NSF-organized conferences in 2017, and at other professional venues (for references, email abhunter@colorado.edu). In press at The Review of Higher Education is, “Finding One’s Place or Losing the Race? The Consequences of STEM Departure for College Dropout and Degree Completion," by You Geon Lee and Joseph Ferrare. We have contracted with Springer to publish our findings in a volume to be titled: Talking about Leaving Revisited: Persistence, Relocation, and Loss in Undergraduate STEM Education. This book should be available in early summer, 2019. Further presentations in the U.S. and internationally are planned for audiences that include deans, directors, and chairs of STEM departments and colleges; faculty advisors; and scholars of STEM education; and funding agencies interested in STEM education reform.
